column1: The study of complex systems regards collective, or system-wide, behaviors as the fundamental object of study; for this reason, complex systems can be understood as an alternative paradigm to [1], which attempts to explain systems in terms of their constituent parts and the individual interactions between them.
When emergence describes the appearance of unplanned order, it is [1] [1] (in the social sciences) or [2]-[2] (in physical sciences).
The notion of self-organizing systems is tied with work in nonequilibrium thermodynamics, including that pioneered by chemist and Nobel laureate Ilya [1] in his study of [2] [2].

A pioneer in the field, and inspired by Karl [1]'s and Warren [2]'s works, Nobel prize economist and philosopher Friedrich [3] dedicated much of his work, from early to the late 20th century, to the study of complex phenomena, not constraining his work to human economies but venturing into other fields such as psychology, biology and cybernetics.
